review_text: I have the NES, SNES, N64 & Gamecube, and a family member has the Wii, I'm a fan of all console's rather than one in particular.I was hesitant to get this after the casual Wii and the failed Wii U, but Breath of the wild was something I wanted to play. I have noticed a few glaring issues with this console.Firstly; it is in some ways poorly designed, an identity crisis with sub par quality in some area's. They made a handheld console you fit into an awkward dock to play on a TV, but can't be played if it isn't charged, and doesn't come with the ¬£50 official controller, meaning you must resort to the small Joy Con's which are greatly inferior (and somewhat small) compared to the other big two. You have to make sure the switch's settings for TV output are auto otherwise it'll strongly to show anything on the correct HDMI setting. This makes TV player's feel like an after thought.You then have their other console the lite, a slightly more underwhelming version which is solely a handheld. It would've been wiser for them to make this switch the handheld only and then a slightly beefed up TV console. Overall, not good design by Nintendo, but this is following the unsuccessful Wii U.Another big negative; the game library. Nintendo used to have a very competitive game library with 1st and 3rd party game's (like on the N64, Goldeneye/Perfect Dark, Conkers Bad Fur Day, Turok etc) after the Game Cube they completely tried to stop competing with the other big two and dropped the more adult game's for more child/family friendly game's (which make the vast bulk of their library and opted for the casual demographic instead of the hardcore.) This is a bit of a kick in the teeth as it means the Switch mainly comprises of it's expected 1st party title's (Zelda, several Mario's etc) and then a swathe of ports unless you want a game targeted for a very niche audience or children. Pretty bad, the N64 was a little difficult to program for and had the restriction of cartridges yet it's game library had powerhouse titles. Maybe the move back to cartridges restricts what can be done on the switch?Another big issue I don't think has ever been brought up, Nintendo (with this console especially) has the market absolutely flooded with cheap and nasty 3rd party products, unofficial products likely from China, that in some cases even try to mimic official Nintendo products (like the Pro Controller). Then there's officially licensed products by Nintendo from other party's, like the PowerA controller etc, whose quality is on the cheap/flimsy side of the spectrum. In all this dumbs down and gives a bit of a wild west free for all experience when trying to get a half decent and quality product, something much easier to avoid on the other big two console's. This is reminiscent of what nearly killed the game industry in the early 80s with no real standard's which ironically Nintendo back then partly saved.There are pro's to this console, it is portable if that's your desire, and there are some very good game's. For children it'll be especially good as the library caters to the casual gamer and children. But the above issues are things to be considered, and hopefully Nintendo will in the future make better design choices to negate all of this. They also need to get more big titles exclusive to the console (new IPs, not ports or the standard one's).It's a tricky console, for the few games that are good, I love it, but in the larger picture, the console is very grating. Also how can they have what is effectively a tablet, and make no use of any streaming platforms? (Netflix and Amazon Prime video at the p least) a real wasted opportunity.
review_title: The harsh truth about this console

    ¬†This was a birthday present to the 5 year old, that came at the right time for us, as we are spending lockdown in a rather small flat, with three kids.Before I describe the specs of the Switch, I'd like to explain why this was selected instead of the Switch Light or the more expensive PS or Xbox.Our older kids are 5 and 6, which is almost the age when they can "do it themselves", but not quite there yet. The operation functions of Nintendo Switch are easily learnt, the kids can set it up themselves and the variety of games Nintendo offers is often in the right mind for children this age - i.e. not so sophisticated or complicated that they would need an adult's help. The Switch Light is a good option of course, especially for a kid with no siblings, but without the ability to hook the console to the tv, it's going to be harder to turn this into a multi participation venue, i.e. only one kids at a time.With the Nintendo Switch, we often see the kids opt for TV game mode, and we can all participate in active games such as "Just Dance" or "Tokyo 2020 Olympics", which the game rewards them through actual movement.Why not PS or Xbox? Well, they're more expensive and as described above sophisticated. So, if you have a very technical child of 10+ maybe they are the better option. For us, the fact that they can hook up the controller themselves and the games are plain and simple was the selling point.What's in the box?===============The Switch condole, a tv hookup hub, a charging cable, 2 Joy Cons (note - 2 Joy Cons makes one whole controller in essence, and some games would require them as such, i.e. you need both per user), and one Joy Con Grip (to combine them to one controller).Game modes:============- The solo mode, as seen on the second picture/the video, provides the kids hours of fun on their own.- The TV hookup (photo 3)1) You can play solo with a big screen. Easy to setup - you just need an empty socket near the tv and an HDMI connection. You then can use the two Joy-Con's with the the controller hub that comes with the switch.2) Another option (for games which allow it) is to use each Joy-Con as a solo controller. The Joy-Cons are gyroscopic and feel the hand movement, so you can play "Just Dance" or "Mario Kart" by moving your hands around. they even provide feedback in terms of vibrations, and remind of the old Wii consoles.- Detaching the JoyCons and using the console as a small screen, this is the worst option but it works too, there's a small leg that allows the console to stand upright (but it tends to fall off, a bit of a design flaw that is negligible since this game mode is not the best anyways).To sum up all the Pro's: hours of fun, interactive games which will keep the kids fit not just in 'zombie' mode, dual game mode as mentioned and adequate for kids up from the age of 5 to setup on their own.To add to that: there are dozens of game around, with genres that fit just about anyone.Con's:=====Not all is perfect with the Nintendo Switch and here are some faults and the way to overcome them (if applicable):- The games are expensive. A new game is around ¬£40, which is not optimal when you want the kids to have a variety. Also, if you bought a game that they didn't like/can't handle - that's money down the toilet.Luckily, the Nintendo Shop has previous and free periods that allow you to test games (but we don't really bother with these).- The Switch comes with two Joy Cons. If you want to play more than two people you will have to get another set, and another grip. while this is relatively cheap, you will then want a charging dock, so you won't have to rotate between them, and it doesn't really end...- You would probably want a screen protector, a travel case, and a few more games... so again when it comes to costs, add at least ¬£100-150 to the original price (and prob more).- The worst thing is the need to subscribe to the Nintendo Shop to be able to play online multi games in several games. this is downright infuriating, as you need to pay for something you already paid for. However, we found that we enjoy the games without the online option as it is.Good games to start with:=====================- Animal Crossings New Horizons - especially for calmer kids who likes building and strategy.- Mario Kart - this is brilliant, the superlatives this game has received are very just, it provides several game modes and hours of fun for all of the family (I enjoy playing with the kids myself, and we get quite competitive)- Just Dance - a good workout in form of dancing with the Joy Cons which will provide hours of fun, but each participant needs a JoyCon.Hope this helped someone to decide whether to get one or not. and If not - feel free to ask questions or comment, or vote this 'helpful' if indeed it was. Thanks and Game on!

I bought a Switch for my son for Christmas. I'm a gamer myself but never had a Switch or used one to any great extent.I had heard all the hype and my son's friends have them hence why I bought one.What surprised me was the numerous negative aspects of the console and it's usablilty.Physically the console is ok but a bit fiddly in my opinion. Removeable joycons is a nice idea but the sticks aren't the best (sometimes pushing up also goes left for example) and when attached to the switch there is a bit of give. Taking them off is fiddly and half the time the shoulder button gets pressed in the process, affecting the game you are playing.The kickstand at the back to hold it up on a table is useless. The console falls over most of the time and my son's came off the first time he tried to stand it up. Reattached ok but terrible quality.I was also surprised how small the screen is. My mobile phone is almost as large.The user interface on the console is ok but could be slicker. A lot of options take two taps to confirm, why?Then we get to the eShop - what a terrible setup. I managed to purchase a game for my son after entering a password THREE times (again, why?) and because I was buying for my son I could not save the card details. So buying another game meant entering all the card details again (oh and entering the password three times again of course).It may have been because it's Christmas Day, but half the time I accessed the eShop it threw a connection error. Trying again it would work but every so often I got the error again. It then refused to download the games I purchased and we awoke the next morning to find they had magically appeared (and it wasn't that it took a while to download, they just weren't on the home screen when first purchased).Finally by the end of the day, the eShop just gave up accepting my card details. I tried two other cards and both of them did not work either. So currently I can't buy any games for my son.Moving on to parental controls. These are iffy on most console in my opinion - the PS4 ones are pretty awful but after a while you can get them set up and then it's ok. Nintendo Switch parental controls are in a whole other league of terrible however, and the restrictions mean I have to purchase games on the console and cannot use the web eShop (which I am trying to do because of my card issue above).I have entered my password to do things so many times on the console that I can type it without looking at the screen now.The games library on the Switch is nothing special to me. There are of course the Mario exclusives which my son likes but other than that, most games are accessible on other (better) consoles, or are just glorified versions of mobile apps. The eShop prices are shocking for most games, so I've opted for physical copies of some games which means a tiny SD card that a child is quite likely to lose.Also on the game sharing side of things - I have another son and another Switch (for my sins). I understand game sharing can't be a free for all because people will take advantage, but even with a Nintendo Online Family Account the game sharing is non-existant. The popular workaround is a nightmare especially when the kids don't understand why Child A needs to use Child B's console. Again, I'm a gamer, I'm used to account setups for these kinds of things but Nintendo take the awkwardness to a whole other level.Plenty of other points to mention about the console, some good and some bad, but the above gripes have led me to write this review (rant). It's an ok console with some ok games, the portable nature is good, but the Nintendo accounts system, eShop and parental controls are terrible. Either that or I've had a few too many glasses of wines over Christmas this year, and the whole thing is actually a doddle.

It was probably quite revolutionary 3 years ago, but as processing power increases in the newer generation of consoles, getting a switch might be a hard sell. Other consoles have more third party support, more games, and you will get the best experience (higher frame rates) on either a PC or a next gen console. That coupled with the issues relating to joycon drift (a problem occurring due to flimsy joysticks) means you'll have to treat them like delicate porcelain.Only get this if:1) You have a strong cult following of Nintendo games (such as I), and are willing to wait patiently (by patiently I mean a good solid 2-3 years) for Nintendo to release their strongest first party titles. This is what it boils down to. Games sell consoles, and Nintendo needs more first party games to compete. And I don't mean constant remasters.2) You're just here to play Nintendo exclusives. Choose a switch for Mario, Pokemon, Zelda, Metroid etc. You will almost always get the worst experience in any other game that's accessible on multiple platforms. Triple A titles from other devs will also give the shaft to the switch in most circumstances, as they demand higher processing power in future titles. Because let's be honest, would you run a game off of a micro SD card or an SSD?3) The convenience of 'switching' between the TV screen and the handheld mode with incredible ease. This is one of the main features that I love, and it distinguishes itself from the competition with its incredible ease of use. No other mainline console does this with such finesse and simplicity, that I have to tip my hat off to Nintendo for this one. It definitely blurs the line between mobile, handheld, and home console gaming.

It cannot sustain decent graphics, it lacks storage space and it lacks a varied and affordable library of games. Yet the console is constantly out of stock.The console is fragile and easily scratched. The Joy-Cons are notoriously fragile and also ridiculously expensive.Many of the games are seriously expensive - ¬£50 for the latest rip-off Pok√©mon? It looks to have improved very little visually over the 3DS excursions and still relies on a tired formula and the con of selling two identical games. Pretty much all games that are found on other consoles are also cheaper for other consoles.So what advantage does the Switch have? It is indeed portable. Not exactly lightweight like the 3DS. I'd want a sturdy case and screen covers before taking this anywhere, and that will be expensive. Family games? That's true. Mario? He's here yet again. Multiplayer? It's a big positive too.Having said all that, you can easily spend about ¬£400 in order to get the Switch, buy protective covers and just one or two games.
